verses.text: The word that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:
verses.comment: Isaiah begins a new prophecy specifically about Judah and Jerusalem, establishing the context for the vision and its scope.

verses.text: In the last days, the mountain of the house of the LORD will be established as the highest of the mountains, raised above the hills, and all nations will stream to it.
verses.comment: This prophecy points to a future time when God's dwelling will be exalted among all nations, foreshadowing the spread of worship to all peoples. The ‘mountain’ often symbolizes God's presence and the unity of believers (see Heb. 12:22).

verses.text: Many peoples will come and say, 'Come, let us go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the house of the God of Jacob, so that He may teach us His ways and that we may walk in His paths.' For out of Zion will go forth the law, and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The pilgrimage of the nations to learn from God anticipates the universal mission of the Church, with the spiritual law spreading from Jerusalem to the whole world (cf. Acts 1:8; Luke 24:47).

verses.text: He will judge between the nations and will settle disputes for many peoples. They will beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks; nation will not lift up sword against nation, nor will they train for war anymore.
verses.comment: This vision of peace looks forward to the messianic age, when God brings lasting harmony. This also has a spiritual sense, as Christ brings peace to the hearts of believers and among nations.

verses.text: O house of Jacob, come, let us walk in the light of the LORD.
verses.comment: A call for God’s chosen people to live according to His light. Spiritually, 'walking in the light' becomes a theme fulfilled in Christ who is the light of the world (John 8:12).

verses.text: For You have rejected Your people, the house of Jacob, because they are full of diviners from the east and practice sorcery like the Philistines and hold hands with foreigners.
verses.comment: Israel’s idolatry and superstition led to God’s discipline. This warns believers against assimilating ungodly practices from surrounding cultures.

verses.text: Their land is full of silver and gold; there is no end to their treasures. Their land is full of horses; there is no end to their chariots.
verses.comment: Trust in wealth and military might is denounced. Spiritual security is found not in possessions, but in faithfulness to God. Israel’s kings were previously warned against amassing such things.

verses.text: Their land is full of idols; they worship the work of their own hands, what their fingers have made.
verses.comment: Condemnation of idolatry, emphasizing how man’s creation cannot replace the Creator. The spiritual message directs believers to adore God alone, not manmade things.

verses.text: So humanity is brought low and each person is humbled—do not forgive them.
verses.comment: Judgment falls on pride and idolatry, highlighting the seriousness of these sins. The corporate responsibility of Israel is emphasized.

verses.text: Go into the rocks, hide in the dust, from the terror of the LORD and the glory of His majesty.
verses.comment: A picture of inescapable judgment. All will eventually have to face God’s glorious presence. Revelation applies this symbolic language to the last judgment.

verses.text: The proud look of man will be humbled, the arrogance of men brought low, and the LORD alone will be exalted on that day.
verses.comment: God alone is worthy of exaltation; humility is the proper attitude before Him. The New Testament repeats this theme in the teachings of Jesus (Luke 18:14).

verses.text: For the LORD of Hosts has a day against all that is proud and arrogant, against all who are exalted—and they will be brought low—
verses.comment: The 'day of the LORD' is a theme of divine judgment, ultimately fulfilled at the end of time. Both individual and collective pride are targeted.

verses.text: against all the cedars of Lebanon, tall and lofty, against all the oaks of Bashan,
verses.comment: Figurative language for human pride and earthly strength that opposes God’s supremacy.

verses.text: against all the lofty mountains and against all the lifted up hills,
verses.comment: Mountains and hills often symbolize powerful nations or leaders set against God.

verses.text: against every high tower and every fortified wall,
verses.comment: Trust in human defenses is futile before God’s judgment.

verses.text: against all the ships of Tarshish and all the splendid vessels.
verses.comment: A sign of worldliness and trade wealth, again demonstrating the futility of trusting in material gains.

verses.text: The proud look of man will be humbled, the arrogance of men brought low, and the LORD alone will be exalted on that day.
verses.comment: Repeats verse 11 to emphasize God’s ultimate exaltation over all human pretensions.

verses.text: The idols will completely vanish.
verses.comment: Ultimate victory of God is shown in the destruction of idolatry. Spiritual lesson: true worship only endures.

verses.text: People will flee into the caves of the rocks and into the holes of the earth, from the terror of the LORD and the glory of His majesty, when He rises to shake the earth.
verses.comment: Isaiah’s picture prefigures the last judgment in Revelation, where all try hiding from God’s wrath, but only repentance and righteousness provide refuge.

verses.text: On that day people will throw away to the moles and bats their silver idols and their gold idols, which they made to worship.
verses.comment: In judgment, reliance on material and false gods becomes exposed as worthless.

verses.text: They will flee into the crevices of the rocks and the clefts of the cliffs, from the terror of the LORD and the glory of His majesty, when He rises to shake the earth.
verses.comment: Repeats verse 19 for emphasis; all will tremble before the revealed glory of God. The persistent warning is meant for repentance.

verses.text: Stop trusting in man, whose breath is in his nostrils—for of what account is he?
verses.comment: A final admonition: trust in God alone rather than fallible men. Spiritual application: true security is found in relationship with the Lord through grace, faith, and obedience.
